claim: If loyalty points had been awarded for the 933 post-2012-01-01 Czech gas station transactions at a rate of 1 point per Czech koruna spent, at least one customer would have exceeded 10,000 points by the end of 2012.
extra_info: Czech Republic can be represented as the Country value in the gasstations table is 'CZE'
reasoning: This is a counterfactual claim. It describes a hypothetical scenario ('If loyalty points had been awarded...') that did not actually occur. The database records actual transactions, not what would have happened under an imagined loyalty points system. Counterfactual claims cannot be verified from a database that only records what actually happened.

content.text:
This claim describes a hypothetical "what if" scenario: "If loyalty points had been awarded..." This is a counterfactual claim — it asks what would have happened under an imagined loyalty points system that doesn't exist in the database.

According to my classification rules, counterfactual claims that describe hypothetical scenarios ("If X had happened...", "Had X been done...", "If X were changed...") cannot be verified from a database that only records what actually happened. These must always be classified as NOT ENOUGH INFO.

```json
{"label": "NOT ENOUGH INFO", "reasoning": "This is a counterfactual claim. It describes a hypothetical scenario ('If loyalty points had been awarded...') that did not actually occur. The database records actual transactions, not what would have happened under an imagined loyalty points system. Counterfactual claims cannot be verified from a database that only records what actually happened."}
```
